source.name: Gapminder
source.additionalInfo: Gapminder dataset. Available online at http://www.gapminder.org/.

66390.name: Real GDP per capita in 2011US$, multiple benchmarks (Maddison Project Database (2018))
66390.description: Measure of real GDP per capita accounts for inflation, i.e. changes in the price level, and this per capita GDP is suitable for cross-country income comparisons.

source.name: Maddison Project Database (2018)
source.dataPublishedBy: Maddison Project Database, version 2018. Bolt, Jutta, Robert Inklaar, Herman de Jong and Jan Luiten van Zanden (2018), “Rebasing ‘Maddison’: new income comparisons and the shape of long-run economic development”, Maddison Project Working paper 10
source.dataPublisherSource: Historical data and reconstructions from a large number of different sources. See the accompanying paper for details
source.additionalInfo:
Full citation: 
Maddison Project Database, version 2018. Bolt, Jutta, Robert Inklaar, Herman de Jong and Jan Luiten van Zanden (2018), “Rebasing ‘Maddison’: new income comparisons and the shape of long-run economic development”, Maddison Project Working paper 10

The original Maddison Project dataset expresses the population "in thousands". In our dataset we have multiplied it by 1000 to avoid expressing it "in thousands".

The Maddison region definitions were adapted from the source from Maddison (2010)'s homepage at: http://www.ggdc.net/maddison/oriindex.htm under the heading "Historical Statistics" and the file titled: Statistics on World Population, GDP and Per Capita GDP, 1-2008 AD (Horizontal file, copyright Angus Maddison, University of Groningen) 

To calculate average real GDP per capita across regions, we have calculated a population weight for each country per year by dividing country population in year x by the total regional population. This weight has been used to multiply real GDP per capita (in 2011US$, with multiple benchmarks) to give real regional GDP per capita weighted by population.

97869.name: Urban population (%) long-run to 2016 (OWID)
97869.description: Share of the population living in urban areas.
97869.datasetName: Urbanization in the long run - OWID based on the UN World Urbanization Prospects 2018 and others
97869.s_name: OWID based on UN World Urbanization Prospects 2018 and others

source.name: OWID based on UN World Urbanization Prospects 2018 and others
source.dataPublishedBy: UN World Urbanization Prospects 2018 and others
source.link: UN: https://esa.un.org/unpd/wup/Download/ (Files 19,20,21); US Census Bureau: https://www.census.gov/population/censusdata/table-4.pdf and https://www.census.gov/prod/cen2010/cph-2-1.pdf (Table 4, page 6); HYDE 3.1: http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/pdf/10.1177/0959683609356587; Bairoch (1988): http://press.uchicago.edu/ucp/books/book/chicago/C/bo5971175.html; De Vries (1984): https://books.google.co.uk/books/about/European_Urbanization_1500_1800.html?id=11yHAAAAIAAJ; Kuroda (1984): http://www.apda.jp/pdf/p04_jinkou_series/popdev_series_3_en.pdf
source.additionalInfo: To construct the long run urbanization series we began with the UN World Urbanization Prospects database covering the period from 1950 to 2050. Then we extended the series backwards using additional data sources including the US Census Bureau, Bairoch (1988), Kuroda (1984), HYDE 3.1 (2010), and De Vries (1984) to arrive at the longest single series possible for each country and region included. For further information on the source used for particular observations by country-year, see the following documentation. To calculate the absolute rural and urban populations, we have multiplied the rural and urban percentages by the historic population series published by Gapminder until 1949 and extended using the UN Population Division data from 1950 to 2016. The long run 'Gapminder + UN Population' population series is available here. For absolute population estimates before 1950 for the 'World', we used the 'World Population over 12,000 years' series. Note: Urbanization data for Japan in 1900 has been excluded as the estimate (HYDE 3.1) was inconsistent with figures for neighbouring years (Kuroda (1986)).
